did.abstract: The records of the Brooklyn Historical Society, founded in 1863 as the Long Island Historical Society. The Society closed in 2020 when it was merged with Brooklyn Public Library to become the Center for Brooklyn History.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The majority of this collection is open to researchers without restriction. Access restrictions are noted at the series or box level.
Materials in the following series are restricted for 20 years from the date of creation:
Series 2: Board and Committee records
Sub-series 10.1: Grants and Gifts: Government
Sub-series 10.2: Grants and Gifts: Foundations and Non-Profits

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The bulk of these records were collected by the institution as part of its recordkeeping. Materials from external sources are noted as such where possible.

altformavail.p: Portions of Series 17: Audiovisual materials have been digitized. Consult CBH staff for more information.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Founded in 1863, the Long Island Historical Society (LIHS)'s mission was to collect and preserve the "history of the United States, the State of New York, and, more particularly, of the counties, cities, towns, and villages of Long Island." Over time, the institutional mission and collection policy narrowed to focus on Brooklyn history, and in 1985 LIHS changed its name to Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS). With these changes came an emphasis on showcasing Brooklyn's diversity, specifically through community-centered exhibitions and educational programming. In 2020, BHS merged with the Brooklyn Collection at the Brooklyn Public Library to form the Center for Brooklyn History.

list.head: Sources:
list.item: The Long Island Historical Society Quarterly, vol. 1, no. 1, Jan. 1939, p. 27.

prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn Historical Society institutional records, ARC.288, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brooklyn Historical Society Institutional records chronicle the topics, events, and departmental activities that are part of the Society's 157-year history. Materials in this collection provide information regarding the landmark building, exhibits, special projects, the library and archives, public programming, education, the Board of Directors, and much more. In addition to documenting how BHS operated, this collection shows how the Society's mission and policies changed over time, as well as the institution's impact on Brooklyn's history and people.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into five sub-series:
Sub-series 1.1: Annual reports, 1894-2000
Sub-series 1.2: Constitution and by-laws, 1863-1985
Sub-series 1.3: Deeds, mortgages, and leases, 1866-1936
Sub-series 1.4: Staff management, 1976-2020
Sub-series 1.5: Strategic planning, 1984-2019

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 1: Administrative, 1863-2020, includes materials related to top-level management of the Society. These materials include annual reports to members and New York State; by-laws and amendments to by-laws; deeds, mortgages, and leases related to 128 Pierrepont Street; files related to union organizing in the 1970s and 1980s; files related to the 1985 name change from LIHS to BHS; and strategic planning proposals.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials can be found throughout the other series in this collection, namely:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 1.1: Annual Reports includes annual reports of the Long Island Historical Society submitted to New York State and sent to members from 1894 to 1958. There are no annual reports from the years 1870-1874 and most of the years post-1966. Annual reports post-1966 can be found in Series 2: Board and Committee records.
This sub-series also includes examples of annual reports and annual appeals from 1997 to 2000 from other New York City- and Brooklyn-based institutions, such as the Brooklyn Museum.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: James Laughlin was on the Board of Directors and Chair of the Building Committee during BHS's renovations in the late 1990s and early 2000s. These renovations included upgrading the building's HVAC system, building the Brooklyn History Discovery Center exhibition space on the ground floor, installing a new elevator, creating a classroom and exhibition space in the cellar, fixes to the building's exterior and roof, and other updates to the building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 2.4: James Laughlin Building Committee files, 1997 - 2002, includes files from the Building Committee that oversaw the building renovations in the late 1990s and early 2000s. The files include correspondence, memos to the Executive Committee and Board of Directors, and plans and agreements produced by the York Hunter construction services.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Women's Committee of the Long Island Historical Society (LIHS) was formed in 1959 to further the objectives of LIHS through fundraising and planning social events. Its creation was initiated by Maud E. Dillard, who served as its president from 1959 to 1964.

The committee organized exhibits, benefits, and tours of historical sites in New York and New Jersey. It also facilitated the Children's History Room program, which sought to teach school children 17th-century Long Island history through the use of maps, photographs, and artifacts. In 1978, the Women's Committee -- and the Children's History Room -- were shut down due to financial hardship, staffing difficulties, and the LIHS staff strike of 1976. After the committee officially dissolved, its resources and efforts were transferred to the "Seated Indian" gift shop.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 2.6: The Women's Committee of the Long Island Historical Society contains annual reports, financial records, meeting minutes, membership lists, brochures, and material related to the Children's History Room program. The financial records include correspondence, dues slips, receipts, bills, and financial reports. The committee kept a file for each major exhibit, benefit, and tour they organized. These files consist of postcards, correspondence, budget information, and invitations.
This sub-series also contains four scrapbooks that document the activities of the Women's Committee through photographs, newspaper clippings, brochures, and other documentation.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Women's Committee scrapbooks were originally stored in binders. Due to preservation concerns, the archivist removed the contents of the scrapbooks from their binders and placed them in acid-free folders. Newspaper clippings were photocopied and discarded.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Executive Director was the title of the person in charge of the Long Island Historical Society and later when the name was changed to the Brooklyn Historical Society. This was the title of the leader of the institution from its inception in 1863 until 1999 when the title was changed to "President" in a revision of the By-Laws.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These files are arranged first according to the director to whom they were either created by or for, or were utilized by during their tenure as executive director. From there, the files are arranged alphabetically according to subject, then arranged chronologically.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The correspondence was kept in its original order and arranged chronologically. The subject files were kept in original order and arranged alphabetically by topic. The subject files were originally arranged topically and grouped together upon arrangement as "Subject Files" to keep consistency with other sub-series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: James P. Hurley's papers are organized into two separate categories: Correspondence and Subject Files.

Files that were originally ordered as "Correspondence" were kept as such and arranged by date. Those files specifically identified as "Correspondence: Invitations" are arranged alphabetically according to the sender. Note that some folders have overlapping dates, as per their original arrangement.

The rest of the materials were arranged as subject files. This title was applied retroactively to various papers that had been originally organized by topic in order to remain consistent with other sub-series.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: James P. Hurley was the Executive Director of the Long Island Historical Society from 1973 until 1978. Prior to his work as the Executive Director of LIHS, he was a research assistant for LIHS circa 1970 and also a historian and professor at the Pratt Institute. While working as a professor at Pratt, Hurley and his students began working on what would become the Weeksville Heritage Project. LIHS (and later, Brooklyn Historical Society) would go on to work closely with Weeksville on exhibits and educational programming.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes those between either Hurley or colleagues from various other institutions, as well as colleagues from within Long Island Historical Society and members of LIHS. There is both ingoing and outgoing correspondence. The subject files contain files that relate to a myriad of topics, from Brooklyn Educational and Cultural Alliance (BECA) to various LIHS materials to grants to legal materials to Erasmus High School and Skidmore College. The Subject Files also contain various types of literature, such as brochures, pamphlets, or publications, some of which are original and some of which are photocopies.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Patricia Flavin was the Head Librarian of the Long Island Historical Society from 1980 until 1983. In 1982, Flavin also served as the Acting Executive Director while the Society was searching for a replacement for Russell Bastedo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Patricia Flavin's papers include correspondence from individuals from other institutions and a legal representative.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These files adhere to three separate classifications according to original arrangement: Correspondence, Subject Files, and Historical Minutes and Policy Statements.

Files that were originally ordered as "Correspondence" were kept as such and arranged by date. Those files specifically identified as "Correspondence: Invitations" are arranged alphabetically according to the sender. Note that some folders have overlapping dates, as per their original arrangement.

Historical Minutes and Policy Statements were originally titled as such and broken down into various categories pertaining to the types of documents. These categories were kept but arranged alphabetically first, followed by chronological order.

The rest of the materials were arranged as subject files. Some of these records had been referred to as such and given subject titles. Other folders were arranged by subject but not referred to as "Subject Files." These files were subsequently added to the subject files during arrangement. Records that were not previously arranged were incorporated into the subject files as well. They are arranged alphabetically and then chronologically.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: David Kahn was the Executive Director of the Society from 1982 to 1996. When he was hired as the Executive Director, the institution was still the Long Island Historical Society. One of the first big changes made under Kahn's leadership was to change the name to the Brooklyn Historical Society in order to more accurately reflect the collection and mission. Despite pushback and litigation, the change eventually happened in 1985. Kahn also wanted to refocus the Society's historical topics to better reflect the diverse communities of Brooklyn that had vastly changed since the founding of the institution in 1863. Kahn wanted to showcase these diverse communities through new exhibits and educational programming, the latter of which had never existed at the institution prior to his appointment. Several successful and diverse exhibits and an education program were established under his directorship before his departure in 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: David Kahn's papers are arranged into three categories based on original arrangement: Correspondence, Subject Files, and Historical Minutes and Policy Statements. The bulk of David Kahn's papers is correspondence, which can be found under both Correspondence and Subject Files. The correspondence includes those between either Kahn (or his assistants) and colleagues from various other institutions, colleagues from within Brooklyn Historical Society, contractors for exhibits, and publishers. There is both ingoing and outgoing correspondence. The subject files also contain various types of literature, such as brochures, pamphlets, or publications, some of which are original and some of which are photocopies. The Historical Minutes and Policy Statements section contains various documents pertaining to planning, policy, and various board minutes.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Irene Tichenor was appointed Acting Executive Director by the Society's Board after the departure of David Kahn. Tichenor was not interested in keeping the position permanently and only held the position while the search continued for a new, permanent Executive Director. She held the position from 1996 until 1998.

processinfo.p: The title of Subject Files was applied retroactively to various papers that had been originally organized by topic.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The title of President originally referred to the head of the Board of Directors. This position lasted with that title from the inception of the Long Island Historical Society in 1863 until 1999.

When the By-Laws were changed in 1999, the title of "President" no longer referred to the head of the Board (that title became the "Chair"). The title of "President" became the title for the former Executive Director position. All presidents after 1999 were the heads of the Brooklyn Historical Society, not the Board. Carol Clark held the role at that time of the title change and, according to Jessie Kelly's oral history, was the one who pushed for the change.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Despite the difference in the positions of President of the Board and President of the Brooklyn Historical Society, these files are kept together because of their use of the same title.

These files are arranged first according to the president to whom they were either created by or for, or were utilized by during their tenure. From there, the files are arranged alphabetically according to subject, then arranged chronologically.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The note is misaddressed to a "John B. Davenport"; there was no John Davenport who was president of the Long Island Historical Society. However, William B. Davenport's ancestor was notably Reverend John Davenport, founder of New Haven colony.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Guy du Val was the President of the Board of Directors of the Long Island Historical Society from 1939 until 1949.

bioghist.head: Historical note

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Irving Choban was heavily involved in the Long Island Historical Society/Brooklyn Historical Society. He served as the LIHS President of the Board of Directors from 1981 until 1984. Outside of that, he continued to serve on the board for many years, including supporting the name change to Brooklyn Historical Society. Choban is also responsible for donating both money and several items in the collections of what is today the Center for Brooklyn History. He had also served as the President of the Flatbush Historical Society for a number of years prior to serving on the board of LIHS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Irving Choban's papers consist of intra-institutional correspondence to and from LIHS members and the Board of Directors.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Susan Mullin's papers are arranged alphabetically by topic.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Susan Mullin joined the Board of Directors in 1981. In June of 1985, Susan Mullin was voted to become the first female president of the Board of Directors in its entire history since it was established in 1863. Only a few months later in October of that same year the institution's name changed from Long Island Historical Society to Brooklyn Historical Society. With the name change, Mullin became not only the first female president of the new Brooklyn Historical Society, but the first president under a new name and mission. Susan Mullin stepped down from her role as President in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Susan Mullin's papers include various amendments to the by laws, a museum conservation plan, and fundraising plans for the Shellens Gallery, as well as materials related to an antiques show.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Carl Ferenbach III served as the President of the Board of Directors of the Brooklyn Historical Soceity from 1990 until 1993. He also served as a member of the board both prior to and after his tenure as President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carl Ferenbach's papers consist of an invitation to the 1994 Founders Ball.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Jessie Kelly's papers are organized as Correspondence and Subject files. The correspondence is arranged chronologically. The subject files are arranged alphabetically.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Jessie Kelly held the title of "President" in two different functions: first as the President of the Board of Directors, then as the President of the Brooklyn Historical Society (formerly referred to as the Executive Director). All materials related to Jessie Kelly were therefore kept together under the President files for this reason, despite the differing functionality of the two roles.
The title of Subject Files was applied retroactively to various papers that had been originally organized by topic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of Jessie Kelly's papers are subject files that were originally arranged according to topic. The bulk of the subject files are various BHS materials, such as the building renovation, grant funding, exhibitions, and by laws. The subject files also include other materials ranging from professional development to the Brooklyn Heights Association and the Flatbush Historical Society.

Jessie Kelly's papers also include correspondence, which includes ingoing and outgoing correspondence from both internally within BHS and externally from other institutions. There is also a collection of outgoing correspondence that Jessie Kelly sent to various celebrities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Carol Clark's papers are arranged alphabetically by topic.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Carol Clark filled the position as head of the Brooklyn Historical Society from 1998 until her departure in 2001. Carol Clark is responsible for instigating the change in the title from Executive Director to President. The change was made official in a 1999 revision of the Society's by-laws. She was also the President of BHS during a major renovation that occurred from 1999 until 2003, after her departure. During this time, BHS operations were run out of an office in the MetroTech campus.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Since there was only one folder originally labeled Correspondence, the archivist decided to integrate it with the alphabetical arrangement, rather than separate it into its own section as was done with other President and Executive Director sub-series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carol Clark's papers include materials related to insurance, the building renovation from the late 90s/early 00s, BHS exhibitions, correspondence, events, fundraising, NEH grants, staffing, and education programming.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Gail Shaffer was President and Executive Officer of Brooklyn Historical Society from October 2001 until her resignation in May 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Deborah Schwartz's papers are arranged alphabetically by topic.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Deborah Schwartz served as the President and CEO of the Brooklyn Historical Society from 2006 until 2020. Schwartz was serving in this position when BHS merged with the Brooklyn Public Library, and departed the institution after the merger was complete.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Since there was only one folder originally labeled Correspondence, the archivist decided to integrate it into the alphabetical arrangement by topic, rather than separate it into its own section as was done with other President and Executive Director sub-series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Deborah Schwartz's papers include materials related to local politicians, BHS exhibitions, correspondence, grants including IMLS and NEH, press coverage, building renovations, auctions, other local institutions, fundraising, donations, legal materials, membership, state funding, president succession plans, records management, strategic planning, and staff materials.

Some of Deborah Schwartz's papers are seemingly duplicates of materials from other series but kept with her sub-series both because they include notes and marginalia from Schwartz and to showcase the subjects and departments she was taking an active interest in while serving within her role as President and CEO.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access

These scrapbooks document the Society's early activities through newspaper clippings, invitations, tickets, and other ephemera. The series also includes loose scrapbook pages primarily from the late 1960s to 1977, which largely consist of newspaper clippings. Additionally, there are two scrapbooks documenting the Society's natural history collection from 1876-1899.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 7.2: Library Department Files contains files that can be attributed to the individuals who served as Head Librarian of the Long Island / Brooklyn Historical Society. This includes George Hannah (1865-1889), Emma Toedteberg (1890-1936), Edna Huntington (1936-1960), Helen P. Bolman (1960-1964), Anne Gordon (1976-1980), Patricia Flavin (1980-1983), Lucinda Manning (1983-1984), Clara Lamers (1983-1986), Irene Tichenor (1988-1996), Michell Hackwelder (1997-1999), and Jeff Barton (2004-2008). Also included are files from Marilyn Petit, Vice President for Collections (2004-2007), Leilani Dawson, Archivist (2005-2008), and Chela Scott Weber, Director of Library and Archives (2009-2011).

The files in this sub-series cover a broad range of topics, including donations, collection acquisitions and sales, deaccessioning, microfilming, digitization, grants and projects, reference statistics, staff involvement in professional organizations, and the development of the Society's cataloging practices for its books, photographs, maps, and archival collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 7.4: Library Correspondence contains incoming and outgoing correspondence of the library spanning from 1862 to 2007. The early correspondence documents various topics such as donations, publication exchanges, membership acceptances and resignations, lecture invitations, and meetings. Many of these letters originate from museums, universities, public libraries, historical societies, banks, booksellers, and individuals seeking assistance with their research. Prominent institutions include The Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences (specifically the Brooklyn Museum), The New York Public Library, the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, and over 30 historical and genealogical societies across the United States.

After 1940, the correspondence primarily consists of reference inquiries regarding genealogy, building history, and local historical topics. These letters also contain information related to memberships, loans, and sales of publications.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Many of the letters were originally stored unfolded in their boxes, rather than being placed in folders. In most cases, the folder title represents the label on the original box. When folders were used, they were often overstuffed. In these instances, the archivist divided the contents into multiple folders but preserved the original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 7.6: Cataloging and Access Projects contains project files for various museum and library initiatives aimed at cataloging and increasing accessibility to the Brooklyn Historical Society's collections, particularly its photographs, maps, and library and archives materials. The majority of these projects focus on cataloging, conservation, and retrospective conversion, which involves converting existing, often manually maintained, library and archive records into computerized or digital formats.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brooklyn Historical Society staff began preparing for the renovation of the building around 1995, starting with inventorying collections for offsite relocation. This preparation and planning lasted until 1999 when the renovation officially began. By 2003, the Great Hall opened to the public, with some museum collections returning to the building. However, library materials were not fully returned until 2006-2007.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The "Library Move Lists" were initially housed in a three-ring plastic binder. The archivist discarded the binder due to preservation concerns but retained the order of the lists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 7.13: Curatorial Department Files includes correspondence, notes, slides, photographs, meeting notes, proposals, and research related to general exhibition planning and artifact acquisition. The files in this sub-series are largely attributed to curatorial staff from the mid-1990s to the mid-2000s. Key individuals include David Kahn (Executive Director, 1982-1996), Ellen Snyder-Grenier (Chief Curator, 1984-1992), Elizabeth Reich (Curator of Exhibitions, 1984-ca. 1989), Sarah Weatherwax (Curator of Collections, 1985-ca. 1988), Rose Garvin-Jackson (Curator of Collections, ca. 1989-ca. 1991), Dwandalyn Reece King (Chief Curator, 1993-circa 1996), Margo Williams (Curator of Collections, 1994-1996), Judith Giuriceo (Curator of Collections and Exhibitions, 1994-1998), and Anne Grant (Curatorial Assistant, ca. 1995-ca. 1996).

Also included are files from subsequent staff, such as Ann Meyerson (Curator of Exhibitions, 1999-2004), Cynthia Sanford (Curator of Collections, ca. 1999-ca. 2004), Wendy Abel-Weiss (Vice President for Exhibits and Education, ca. 2001-ca. 2005), and Deslyn Downes (Curatorial Assistant, ca. 2001-ca. 2005).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Under the direction of Head Librarian Irene Tichenor (1988-1996), the library undertook a deaccessioning project in the early 1990s to refine its collection. Tichenor began identifying and preparing out-of-scope materials for removal between 1991 and 1995. In December 1995, she hired Bob Heman as Collections Manager to oversee this task.

Lot subjects are detailed at the file level.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Initially a division, Public History at the Brooklyn Historical Society consisted solely of Julie Golia, who was hired in March 2011 as BHS's Public Historian. The Public History Department was formally established in 2015 following the hiring of Zaheer Ali as Oral Historian. The department oversaw major history initiatives, including Waterfront, Taking Care of Brooklyn, Voices of Crown Heights, and Muslims in Brooklyn. Staff members also served as public representatives and experts to both the public and the press.

The department provided historical oversight for history content across BHS departments and worked closely with Library and Collections staff. In November 2018, President Deborah Schwartz formalized this relationship by merging the Public History and Library and Archives departments to create the Curatorial Affairs and Collections department, appointing Julie Golia as Vice President overseeing the new department.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional materials related to the work of the Public History Department can be found in the following sub-series:

Sub-series 8.8: Waterfront at Brooklyn Historical Society DUMBO Sub-series 8.9: Taking Care of Brooklyn: Stories of Sickness and Health Sub-series 9.5: Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations Sub-series 9.6: Voices of Crown Heights Sub-series 9.7: Muslims in Brooklyn

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 7.16: Public History Department Files contains administrative and general files maintained by the Public History Department of the Brooklyn Historical Society. This includes material related to project planning, research, expenses, the Flatbush + Main podcast, and tours offered by the Society. The files in this sub-series are attributed to Julie Golia, who served as the Director of Public History (2011-2018) and the Vice President for Curatorial Affairs and Collections (2018-2019).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes material related to the creation of Flatbush + Main, the Brooklyn Historical Society's podcast co-hosted by Zaheer Ali and Julie Golia. Launched in April 2016, Flatbush + Main was a monthly podcast dedicated to telling Brooklyn's history through conversations with scholars and researchers, as well as explorations of BHS's collections.

did.unittitle: Sub-series 7.17: Students and Faculty in the Archives (SAFA)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged first in chronological order, and then alphabetically by folder title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Students and Faculty in the Archives (SAFA) was a Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS) project funded by the U.S. Department of Education's Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education (FIPSE). The Society collaborated with 18 faculty members from three colleges: Long Island University Brooklyn, New York City College of Technology (City Tech), and Saint Francis College. Over the course of three years, two full-time project co-directors developed an instructional program at BHS. They partnered with faculty from these colleges to design and deliver courses aimed at enhancing engagement and learning for first and second-year undergraduates through hands-on analysis of original primary source documents.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: W-9 tax forms and sign-in sheets were removed and destroyed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 7.17: Students and Faculty in the Archives (SAFA) includes evaluations, sample handouts, release forms, financial records, and grant documentation related to the application and management of the U.S. Department of Education's Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education (FIPSE). It also contains promotional material, transcriptions, and reproductions created for the exhibition Exploring the Journals of Gabriel Furman, a product of the SAFA Summer Fellowship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, budgets, a grant proposal, and other documentation related to the application and management of the U.S. Department of Education's Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education (FIPSE).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 8: Exhibitions and Special Projects documents the research, development, and implementation of both temporary and permanent exhibitions curated by library, curatorial, and public history staff at the Brooklyn Historical Society. The materials include object checklists, brochures, correspondence, installation photos, exhibition labels and scripts, press coverage, research materials, posters, promotional materials, and audiovisual media. Most of the documentation covers exhibitions curated between 1982 and 2007, with fewer records for those prior to 1970, and predominantly born-digital records post-2005.

did.unittitle: Sub-series 8.1: The Long Island Historical Society Museum

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1865, the Natural History Department of the Long Island Historical Society was established under the leadership of Elias Lewis, Jr., who served as the department's chairman. In addition to this role, he held various other positions within the Society, including secretary, museum curator, and board member.

The museum displayed its natural history collection along with other items referred to as "curiosities" and "relics" from Long Island and around the world. The exhibits included taxidermy animals (primarily birds, reptiles, and small mammals), Revolutionary War-era surgical instruments, geological specimens (such as local rocks, pebbles, and soils), firearms, and human remains (including skulls, ulnas, and femurs). The Society also collected a significant number of arrowheads, spearheads, stone implements, and other objects associated with indigenous peoples in the United States and abroad.

In 1926, due to financial difficulties, the LIHS closed its natural history department and donated its collections to other institutions in New York, such as the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the Museum of the American Indian.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Elias Lewis, Jr. letters, 1853-1894 (2013.002); Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.1: The Long Island Historical Society Museum contains lists of donations made to the museum department, museum and lecture reports, special committee proceedings, and other documentation pertaining to the Long Island Historical Society's museum. Additionally, this sub-series includes a museum accessions catalog and a natural history scrapbook. The accessions catalog serves as the primary record of the museum's contents, while the natural history scrapbook provides details about the museum's activities from the mid-1880s to 1900. The scrapbook includes newspaper clippings, meeting minutes, ephemera, and correspondence related to the donation of specimens and artifacts to the museum.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged chronologically by project occurrence, with files for each project arranged alphabetically by file title. Files for Documenting Brooklyn appear at the end in alphabetical order.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Beginning in the late 1980s, the Brooklyn Historical Society conducted five documentation projects focused on Brooklyn's Latino Communities, the AIDS crisis, Crown Heights, the Chinese community in Sunset Park, and the annual West Indian Carnival celebration. These projects were part of BHS's initiative to make the Society more responsive to – and its collections more reflective of – contemporary Brooklyn. Each community study involved two phases: research and dissemination. Research involved collecting oral history interviews, documents, photos, and artifacts. Dissemination was mainly done through exhibitions using the collected materials. To help conduct these projects, scholarly and community advisory committees were formed for each study. Committee members identified candidates for oral history interviews, sites to be photographed, and sources for documents and artifacts.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.2: Community Documentation Projects records from the five community documentation projects that BHS staff conducted from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s: Brooklyn's Hispanic Communities/Our Borough's Latino Voices, AIDS/Brooklyn, the Crown Heights History Project, Brooklyn's West Indian Carnival, and Eighth Avenue: Sunset Park's Chinese/American Community. Materials include photographs, research materials, press releases, journal articles, public relations material, and documentation related to the administration of each project, particularly during exhibition development. Audiovisual content includes recordings of advisory committee meetings and exhibition videos providing an overview of some of the projects.

This sub-series also contains correspondence, notes, and drafts related to Documenting Brooklyn (also referred to as The New Brooklyn), an unpublished collection of essays about each documentation project, written by their respective project directors. Authors include Ellen M. Snyder-Grenier (Chief Curator, 1984-1992), Dr. Jill Vexler, Robert Rosenberg, Dr. Craig Wilder, Greg Ruff, and Dwandalyn Reece King (Chief Curator, 1992-1995). The book was co-edited by Executive Director David Kahn (1982-1996) and Professor Philip Kasinitz.

did.unittitle: Sub-series 8.3: In Pursuit of Freedom: African Americans and the Antislavery Movement

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In Pursuit of Freedom: African Americans and the Antislavery Movement was a year-long project that resulted in a traveling exhibition and educational materials. The exhibition explored the role played by Brooklynites, particularly African Americans, in the movement to end slavery in the United States and prominently featured an original copy of the Emancipation Proclamation signed by Abraham Lincoln.

After its opening at City Hall in Manhattan on September 22, 1997, the exhibition traveled to multiple locations in Brooklyn, including Borough Hall, the Bedford Stuyvesant Restoration Corp, and several branches of the Brooklyn Public Library. Beginning in 2008, a decade after the conclusion of In Pursuit of Freedom: African Americans and the Antislavery Movement, a separate public history initiative, also titled In Pursuit of Freedom, continued to explore similar themes and expand upon the groundwork laid by the initial project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.3: In Pursuit of Freedom: African Americans and the Antislavery Movement contains correspondence, research files, photographs, meeting minutes, promotional material, and documentation related to exhibition design and curriculum development.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brooklyn's History Museum (1989-1999) was purportedly the first-ever long-term exhibition on the borough's history. Sections were organized around five symbols of Brooklyn: the Brooklyn Bridge, the Brooklyn Navy Yard, Brooklynites, Coney Island, and the Brooklyn Dodgers. Under the direction of Chief Curator Ellen Snyder-Grenier (1984-1992), the symbols were chosen for their familiarity and used as entry points to building broader interpretations of Brooklyn's history.

The exhibition was installed in the Shellens Gallery of Brooklyn History, also known as the Shellens Gallery. The space was named in honor of Ruth M. Shellens, whose estate contributed $350,000 to the project, marking the largest single gift or grant received by the Historical Society for this initiative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.4: Brooklyn's History Museum includes correspondence, installation photos, separation and transfer forms, project planning documentation, and catalog worksheets. The catalog worksheets describe the condition and provenance of the objects used in the exhibition. These worksheets are similar to the 'Shellens Rejects forms,' which contain information about objects staff considered for inclusion in Brooklyn's History Museum, but decided not to use.

Sub-series 8.5: Brooklyn Works: 400 Years of Making a Living in Brooklyn

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this subseries are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brooklyn Works: 400 Years of Making a Living in Brooklyn was a major exhibition that told the story of labor and industry in Brooklyn, starting with its agricultural beginnings and ending with stories of contemporary workers in various industries. Brooklyn Works was the Society's inaugural exhibition upon the reopening of its historic building in October 2003, following an extensive renovation that began in 1999. The exhibit highlighted historical and contemporary personal narratives, featured several interactive activities, and showcased different work environments, including Bush Terminal, a tenement building, a sugar refinery, a garment factory, and a barbershop.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.5: Brooklyn Works: 400 Years of Making a Living in Brooklyn documents the development of Brooklyn Works, from its original conceptualization in the early 1990s to its deinstallation in 2006. Materials include correspondence, meeting minutes, photographs, NEH grant records, scripts, research files, design plans, and audio-visual media containing the images and audio programs used in the exhibition. The bulk of this material comes from the files of Ann Meyerson, Curator of Exhibitions (1999-2004), Wendy Aibel-Weiss, Vice President for Exhibits and Education (ca. 2001-ca. 2005), and Deslyn Downes, Curatorial Assistant (ca. 2001-ca. 2005).

A substantial portion of this sub-series consists of periodization files. These files detail the historical background, narratives, images, objects, and archival materials used for each section of Brooklyn Works. The scope and topics highlighted change throughout the exhibit planning process, but the final periods are as follows: Period 1 – Bounty and Bondage: Kings County before 1820; Period 2 – The World Trades with Brooklyn: 1820-1880; Period 3 – Brooklyn, A Powerhouse of Production: 1880-1950; Period 4 – Industry Shifts Gears, Brooklyn Today: 1950-2000. Many of these files contain reproductions of primary and secondary sources used to develop each period. The dates attributed to these files reflect their reproduction dates rather than their original creation or publication.

Also included in this sub-series are records pertaining to Worklore: Brooklyn Workers Speak, a traveling exhibition and website version of Brooklyn Works co-sponsored by the Brooklyn Public Library. This multimedia exhibit chronicled the work lives of Brooklynites over the last 100 years through audio recollections and historic photographs.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: To ensure like materials are grouped together, the archivist altered the original folder titles for the grant, periodization, research, and Worklore files.

did.unittitle: Sub-series 8.6: In Pursuit of Freedom / Brooklyn Abolitionists

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this subseries are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In Pursuit of Freedom was a multifaceted public history project that explored and traced the history of abolitionism, anti-slavery, and the Underground Railroad in Brooklyn. The project was a collaboration between three Brooklyn cultural institutions: Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS), Weeksville Heritage Center (WHC), and Irondale Ensemble Project (IEP). In Pursuit of Freedom resulted in three interactive exhibits, an educational curriculum, public programs, walking tours, a website, and an original theater piece by Irondale Ensemble Project. The exhibitions traced the history of abolitionist Brooklyn and provided visitors with the opportunity to read and explore images, primary source documents, original land-use maps, sermons, and editorials about the draft riots and fugitive slave laws. The BHS exhibit, Brooklyn Abolitionists, was a major, long-term exhibition that explored the lesser-known individuals of Brooklyn's anti-slavery movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.6: In Pursuit of Freedom / Brooklyn Abolitionists documents the development of the public history project In Pursuit of Freedom (IPOF), with emphasis on its funding, research, and execution. Materials include grant proposals, meeting agendas, meeting minutes, research reports, budgets, evaluations, and files concerning exhibition and curriculum development.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Public Perspectives Exhibition Series (2006-2011) provided a platform for Brooklyn-based individuals, community-based organizations, and school groups to contribute to the Brooklyn Historical Society by curating community exhibitions. Each year, BHS issued an open call for exhibition proposals, which were reviewed by a panel of cultural and community representatives. Once selected, the awardees collaborated with BHS staff to develop and mount their exhibitions.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Curator tax documentation and resumes were removed and destroyed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.7: Public Perspectives Exhibition Series contains files pertaining to the administrative and curatorial components of the Public Perspectives Exhibition Series. The bulk of the material consists of Exhibit Files, which include proposals, agreements, work plans, and other documentation produced throughout the execution of all 12 exhibits in the series. Additionally, these files include audiovisual media consisting of images, videos, and slideshows used for the exhibits.

Sub-series 8.8: Waterfront at Brooklyn Historical Society DUMBO

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Located in the Empire Stores building at 55 Water Street, Brooklyn Historical Society DUMBO was BHS's first satellite gallery. Under the direction of Public Historian Julie Golia (2011-2020) and Project Manager Paul Pearson, BHS DUMBO hosted Waterfront (2018-2020), an exhibition that explored the human and natural history of Brooklyn's waterfront. The exhibition addressed themes such as labor and commerce, environmental history, sea level rise, gender, race, art, and gentrification.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional material on Brooklyn Historical Society DUMBO can be found in Sub-series 5.1: BHS DUMBO.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.8: Waterfront at Brooklyn Historical Society DUMBO includes research files, meeting minutes, promotional materials, manuals, exhibition scripts, an object list, and visitor feedback related to the Waterfront exhibition at Brooklyn Historical Society DUMBO.

Sub-series 8.9: Taking Care of Brooklyn: Stories of Sickness and Health

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Taking Care of Brooklyn: Stories of Sickness and Health, also known as "Sick," explored how centuries of Brooklynites understood sickness and health through a social, historical, and scientific lens. Taking Care of Brooklyn closed prematurely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and was BHS's last major exhibition before it merged with the Brooklyn Public Library in 2020.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 8.9: Taking Care of Brooklyn: Stories of Sickness and Health contains documentation related to the development and execution of Taking Care of Brooklyn, including meeting notes, an object checklist, an exhibition script, and an exhibition manual. Additionally, there are files concerning research conducted by the Public Health Research Fellow and Assistant Curator, Erin Wuebker.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Brooklyn Historical Society began collecting oral histories in 1973 with the Puerto Rican Oral History Project. Following this project, BHS staff collected oral histories on a project basis, primarily for use in exhibitions. In 2006, BHS instituted an Oral History Program with Sady Sullivan as the Director of Oral History (2006-2014). In 2017, BHS launched its oral history portal, which made hundreds of oral history interviews accessible to the public online. Before BHS's merger with the Brooklyn Collection at the Brooklyn Public Library in 2020, the oral history collections included over 1,200 interviews.

scopecontent.p: Series 9: Oral History consists of administrative and project files generated by the oral history program from its inception in 2006 through 2019. It includes policies, procedures, research, correspondence, marketing materials, and project planning documentation related to several extensive oral history projects. The majority of these files were created by Sady Sullivan, Director of Oral History (2006-2014), and Zaheer Ali, Oral Historian (2015-2020).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Voices of Brooklyn oral history collection includes interviews collected through several projects undertaken by the Brooklyn Historical Society beginning in 2006. The series started in 2008 as "Brooklyn History Makers" and was renamed in 2016. It features narrators such as civic leaders, artists, community activists, business owners, athletes, veterans, and other Brooklyn residents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 9.2: Voices of Brooklyn Oral Histories includes interview guides, correspondence, and research materials related to the individuals interviewed for the Voices of Brooklyn oral history series.

did.unittitle: Sub-series 9.3: Brooklyn Navy Yard Oral Histories

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Brooklyn Navy Yard oral history collection is the result of two collecting projects. The first effort took place from 1986 to 1989. The second effort, spanning from 2006 to 2010, was a partnership between the Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS) and the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation (BNYDC). This latter project aimed to capture the voices of those who worked at the Navy Yard during World War II and document the evolution of women joining the labor force during the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

arrangement.head: Arrangement

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 2010, the Brooklyn Historical Society partnered with the Brooklyn School of Inquiry (PS/IS 686), a public citywide Gifted and Talented school founded in 2009, to document its growth through oral histories. The resulting collection consists of over 400 interviews with elementary school-age children who attended the school, including annual interviews with the first class as the students progressed through each grade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 9.4: Brooklyn School of Inquiry includes correspondence, notes, contracts, interview questions, meeting notes, and project planning documentation related to the Brooklyn School of Inquiry oral history project.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by file title. Releases and narrator files appear at the end.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations (2011-2015) was a multi-year oral history project and public programming series focused on the history and experiences of mixed-heritage individuals and families, cultural hybridity, race, ethnicity, and identity in Brooklyn. Directed by Sady Sullivan, Director of Oral History from 2006 to 2014, the project involved a team of 25 interviewers who conducted over 100 oral history interviews with individuals identifying as mixed heritage. In addition to the interviews, the project produced an interpretive website featuring these oral histories, essays, and educational resources. Funding for Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations was provided by the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS), the New York Council for the Humanities (NYCH), and several other organizations.

scopecontent.p: Sub-series 9.5: Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations includes research, promotional materials, financial records, and files related to project planning and website development. It also contains grant documentation for funding received from the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS), and the New York Council for the Humanities (NYCH).

Additionally, this sub-series consists of narrator files, which include unedited transcripts, checklists, and releases. Narrator files containing unedited interview transcripts and audio recordings are noted at the file level.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Voices of Crown Heights was a multi-year oral history project focused on the transformation of Crown Heights. It engaged community members in discussions on education, police accountability, community safety, and civic responsibility. The project resulted in a collection of oral histories conducted by the Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS), Brooklyn Movement Center (BMC), and Weeksville Heritage Center (WHC) starting in 2016, which BHS collected and arranged in 2017.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Voices of Crown Heights oral histories, 2016-2017 (2016.027)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 9.6: Voices of Crown Heights contains correspondence, meeting notes, grant documentation, interview and discussion guides, and research materials related to the Voices of Crown Heights oral history project.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by file title.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 2017, the Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS) launched Muslims in Brooklyn, a multi-year public arts and history project designed to amplify the stories of Brooklyn's Muslim communities. This multidisciplinary initiative included an educational curriculum, an art exhibition, and a series of public conversations and performances. Central to the project were over fifty oral history interviews with Muslim Brooklynites conducted by the society in 2018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 9.7: Muslims in Brooklyn contains materials related to the development and management of the exhibition, curriculum, and oral history collection components of Muslims in Brooklyn, including consulting agreements, manuals, guides, promotional materials, and research documents. The bulk of these files were created by Zaheer Ali, the project director of Muslims in Brooklyn and Oral Historian at the Brooklyn Historical Society from 2015 to 2020.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials documenting the activities of the Brooklyn Historical Society's development department. The department was responsible for raising funds to support the Society's mission, operations, and programs.

The bulk of this series documents the department's efforts to identify relevant grant-making agencies, grant applications, grant reports, and correspondence. Agencies include local, State, and Federal government; foundations, non-profits, and corporations. Grants both awarded and denied are documented, as well as efforts to reappropriate awarded funds. Gifts provided for general operations and program support are also included in these sub-series.

The earliest materials in this series are found in the memberships sub-series. Bound volumes with member names and addresses date to early in the Society's founding. Later membership reports, payment receipt books, member correspondence, and printed mailers are also included. Money raised for general operating costs outside of memberships and grants is documented in the fundraising sub-series. Also included in this sub-series are planning materials for annual fundraising dinners and donor events, as well as invitations, menus, photographs, and invite lists. The fundraising sub-series also includes paperwork regarding bequests.

Strategic planning materials include committee meeting notes, presentations, and trend forecasts concerning short-term and long-term fundraising planning, donor and membership cultivation, and updated mission planning for the development office and Brooklyn Historical Society as whole. The campaigns sub-series holds planning materials and final products created under the direction of the development department for various advertising campaigns. The press sub-series includes newspaper and magazine clippings with various announcements concerning the Brooklyn Historical Society and other organizations and individuals associated with the Society.

This series includes materials that were generated prior to the creation of the development department (i.e. materials that would retroactively be considered development, but created under the Long Island Historical Society).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in eight sub-series:
Sub-series 10.1: Grants and Gifts: Government is arranged alphabetically in loose chronological order
Sub-series 10.2: Grants and Gifts: Foundations and Non-Profits is arranged alphabetically in loose chronological order
Sub-series 10.3: Grants and Gifts: Businesses and Corporations is not arranged
Sub-series 10.4: Memberships is not arranged
Sub-series 10.5: Fundraising is not arranged
Sub-series 10.6: Strategic Planning is not arranged
Sub-series 10.7: Campaigns is not arranged
Sub-series 10.8: Press is not arranged

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The bulk of records in the development series were identified during a 2025 inventory, unarranged. However, a small portion of the development department's files were originally arranged alphabetically under the following headings:
Grants: paperwork pertaining to various grants.
Partnerships: materials concerning institutions that had partnerships with the Brooklyn Historical Society at some point in their history, usually through grants and gifts.
Foundations: materials concerning foundations and non-profits that financially supported the Brooklyn Historical Society through grants and gifts.
Corporations: materials concerning corporations that financially supported the Brooklyn Historical Society through grants and gifts.
NYC Government Grants: grant materials from New York City government agencies.
Federal Grants: grant materials from United States government agencies.
State Grants: grant materials from New York State agencies.
To enhance discoverability the archivist interfiled records found during the inventory, imposed new headings (sub-series titles), updated folder titles and dates.
All original newspaper clippings and check copies were discarded after preservation photocopies were made.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The development department was formally created in the late 1980s, although activities that would later fall under the purview of the department, such as memberships and grants, were actively managed by various staff members before the department's creation. Anne Rehkopf Townsend served as the first Director of Development from 1996-1998 and from 2002-2006. Townsend was followed by Fred Bush (1999-2001), Stephanie Kornfeld (2006-2008), Sally Marshall (2009-2012), Arlene Swartz (2012), Jennifer Beirne (2013-2016), and Heather Malin (2016-2020).

accessrestrict.p: Materials in sub-series 10.1 and 10.2 are restricted until 2045. Exceptions may be granted on a case-by-case basis. Please contact the Center for Brooklyn History for more information.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional grant materials can be found in sub-series 7.15.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains materials related to grants awarded by New York City, New York State, and Federal government agencies, dating from the early 1970s to 2020. Records include grant applications, correspondence with funding agencies, interim and final reports, payment documentation, and supporting materials. The grants supported a range of initiatives including public programs, exhibitions, building restoration, educational programs, digitization projects, and the acquisition of upgraded equipment and technology. Grants awarded for conservation and preservation projects often include collection inventories and treatment reports. Items in the Politicians: New York City folder include correspondence regarding money allocated to the Brooklyn Historical Society from the city's discretionary fund.
Materials also include applications and correspondence for grants that were not awarded.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Education Department at the Brooklyn Historical Society was formally established in 1984. The staff were responsible for coordinating school group visits, developing curricula, hosting teacher workshops, and facilitating after-school and internship programs. They also planned public programs, including walking tours, lectures, panel discussions, workshops, and other events that highlighted both the Society's exhibitions and various topics in Brooklyn history.

The Education Department managed most public programs until 2013, when Marcia Ely was hired as Vice President of Programs and External Affairs. As a result, the department shifted its focus to school programming, curriculum design, and teacher professional development workshops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 11: Education Department Records contains records produced by the education department of the Brooklyn Historical Society from its inception in 1984 until 2020. This material documents school and public programming, exhibition and curriculum development, after-school programs, grant-funded projects, marketing, research, and the department's administrative work, including manuals, policies, and procedures.

The bulk of the files in this series are attributed to education department leadership. This includes Joyce Crawford (Curator of Education, 1984-1987), Jane Emmet (Curator of Education, 1987-circa 1991), Fabiana Chiu (Curator of Education, 1991-1993), Laura Miller (Director of School Programs, circa 1990-1993 and Curator of Education, 1993-1995), Rebecca Krucoff (Curator of Education, 2001-2003), Andrea Del Valle (Education Coordinator, 2003-2004 and Director of Education, 2004-2013), Kate Fermoile (VP for Exhibits and Education, 2002-2011 and Manager of Special Projects, 2011-2015), Emily Potter-Ndiaye (Education Coordinator, 2009-2012; Manager of Teaching and Learning, 2012-2013; and Director of Education, 2013-2018), Sonnet Takahisa (Director of Education, 2019-2020), and Shirley Brown Alleyne (Manager of Teaching and Learning, 2015-2020).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In the late 1980s, the Education Department of the Brooklyn Historical Society launched the Brooklyn Life Project—an initiative to collect stories from Brooklyn residents about their lives in the borough. Under the direction of Madeline Slovenz (Coordinator of the Brooklyn Life Project), and later Diane Esses, the department interviewed dozens of Brooklyn natives. The call for Brooklyn Life Associates was open to all, with special emphasis on the narratives of older patrons. Many of these stories were then featured in public programming or in the "Brooklynites" section of Brooklyn's History Museum, the first long-term exhibition on the borough's history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 11.2: Brooklyn Life Project contains release forms, interview notes, and basic data forms. The basic data forms document the interviewee's name, address, age, birthplace, how they heard about the project, the neighborhoods they lived in, highlights of their Brooklyn experience, and comments from project staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 11.3 contains curricula, teacher's guides, lesson plans, and kits developed by the educators at the Brooklyn Historical Society for both museum and classroom instruction. Many of the early curricula focus on Brooklyn Historical Society exhibitions, while later materials cover a range of historical topics, including the development of penicillin, enslavement and abolition, the history of sports, Dutch Brooklyn, and more. The kits include laminated images from the BHS collection and a teacher's guide with detailed lesson plans, historical overviews, and connections to learning standards.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: From its establishment in 1984 until 2013, the Education Department was responsible for all public programming at the Brooklyn Historical Society. This included walking tours, lectures, panel discussions, workshops, and multicultural programs, such as cultural performances, children's activities, crafts, slide presentations, and parties. While the topics of these programs varied, they were typically linked to the ongoing exhibitions.

In 2013, Marcia Ely was hired as Vice President of Programs and External Affairs, leading to the creation of a separate public programming department. As a result, the Education Department shifted its focus to school programming and teacher professional development workshops.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 2001, the Brooklyn Historical Society, in collaboration with Hofstra University and the New York City Department of Education, received a Teaching American History Grant for the Gateway to the City project. Over three years, this grant facilitated staff development, provided resources such as books and technology for classrooms, and supported the public showcasing of teachers' projects.

Gateway to the City aimed to familiarize teachers and students with the wealth of historical resources accessible in New York City through curated trips, access to primary sources, and thematic programs. Hofstra University professors provided pedagogical support, while Lynda Kennedy, BHS's Manager of Teacher Outreach (2001-2003), assisted teachers with materials, staff development, and field trips. Additionally, the project included an annual Summer Institute for teachers to develop curriculum units, participate in technology and primary source workshops, and engage with New York City history scholars.

processinfo.head: Processing Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 11.9: Gateway to the City contains correspondence, teacher reflections, meeting notes, lesson plans, and other documentation pertaining to the activities of the Gateway to the City project, with an emphasis on field trip planning, grant administration, teacher recruitment, and the annual Summer Institute.

This file contains incoming and outgoing correspondence, school visit data collection forms, workshop feedback forms, and documentation related to the implementation of the Teaching American History grant.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Launched in 2004, Town Criers: Young Curators Reveal Historical News was a three-year partnership between the Brooklyn Historical Society and three Brooklyn high schools: Midwood High School (2004-2005), Paul Robeson High School (2005-2006), and Cobble Hill High School of American Studies (2006-2007). Each year, BHS museum staff and subject area specialists collaborated with students to create a traveling exhibition and an original theatrical production that illustrated how national events influenced everyday life in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 11.10: Town Criers: Young Curators Reveal Historical News includes exhibition and performance scripts, handouts, school plans, exhibition panel text, and pre-and post-program surveys for all three Brooklyn schools that participated in the Town Criers program. It also contains grant documentation, including the application, award notification, and reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lynda Kennedy served as a consultant for the Town Criers project. This file includes invoices, correspondence, and memos of understanding.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Exhibition Laboratory (ExLab) was an afterschool program launched by the Brooklyn Historical Society in 2006 to expand its educational offerings to high school students. Participants, ranging from 9th to 12th grades, researched and prepared all aspects of Brooklyn-related exhibits. This included selecting artifacts, writing exhibit scripts, preparing object labels, collaborating with design teams, and installing the exhibits. The program concluded in 2015 when it became difficult to sustain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 11.11: Exhibition Laboratory (Ex Lab) consists of materials related to the development, execution, and assessment of the Exhibition Laboratory exhibitions. It includes object lists, postcards, scripts, labels, panel designs, and visitor feedback. Additionally, this sub-series contains materials pertaining to the instructional components of the program, including lesson plans, handouts, and student evaluations.

arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are organized in ascending order by school numbers.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Young Curators was an after-school program where students researched and curated exhibits about their school's neighborhood. Over a dozen elementary and middle schools participated, with each school producing three professionally designed exhibit panels that were displayed within their premises. Guided by BHS staff, the students researched a topic in their neighborhood's history, analyzed primary and secondary sources, and communicated their findings through the exhibit panels. The program ended in 2015 when the Young Scholars program was introduced at P.S. 312 in Bergen Beach. Both programs received funding through Cultural After School Adventure (CASA) grants from local City Council members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 11.12: Young Curators afterschool program contains correspondence, invoices, lesson plans, photographs, student work, and administrative files related to the Young Curators afterschool program.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: As of April 2024, digital versions of these publications are available on the Center for Brooklyn History website.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this sub-series are arranged alphabetically by title.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Young Scholars was an after-school program where students conducted research and authored books on topics related to Brooklyn's history. The initiative stemmed from the Brooklyn Historical Society's Young Curators program, in which students participated in researching and curating exhibits about their school's neighborhood. Both programs received funding through Cultural After School Adventure (CASA) grants from local City Council Members.

The books published as part of the Young Scholars program cover a range of topics, including sewers, cemeteries, freedom and abolition, the Brooklyn Bridge, immigration, the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the sugar industry, and various Brooklyn neighborhoods.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The archivist preserved two copies of each publication. Surplus copies were discarded.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Young in Brooklyn is the product of a four-month Remembering Brooklyn partnership between the Brooklyn Historical Society and Mill Basin Center Active Adult Program. Stemming from the Young Scholars program, the Remembering Brooklyn program was designed to capture memories of Brooklyn from its older adult populations and put them in dialogue with related archival collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Brooklyn Educational and Cultural Alliance (BECA) was an educational and cultural consortium chartered in June 1975 by the New York State Board of Regents. It included the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM), Brooklyn Botanic Garden, The Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Public Library, Long Island University – Brooklyn Center, Polytechnic Institute of New York, Pratt Institute, St. Francis College, St. Joseph's College, and, as an Associate Member, The Long Island Historical Society. The consortium's major educational, cultural, and community service outreach program was its Voucher Program, which started as an experimental six-week pilot project in Spring 1978 and evolved into an eight-month program. The Voucher Program utilized the resources and expertise of the member institutions of BECA in developing programs and services for Brooklyn community organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 12.2: Brooklyn Education & Cultural Alliance (BECA) contains voucher program booklets, resource directories, correspondence, and voucher program request and completion forms, which provide details about the programs and services offered by BECA member institutions. This sub-series also includes a proposal and a collections survey related to Brooklyn Rediscovery, a BECA program designed to develop humanistic projects addressing Brooklyn's physical, social, educational, cultural, and economic growth and heritage.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1938, to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Society's founding, the Directors of the Long Island Historical Society launched an official quarterly journal. The journal aimed to publish rare manuscripts held by the Society, along with articles of historical interest covering various subjects related to Long Island. The first issue was published in January 1939, but wartime conditions forced LIHS to cease publication of the Quarterly in 1942.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The archivist preserved at least two copies of each quarterly. Surplus copies were discarded.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Long Island in History series of the Edgerton Grant North Publication Fund was a collection of history pamphlets created for elementary school children. Publishing Long Island history materials for students was an area of interest for Edgerton Grant North, president of the Long Island Historical Society from 1957 to 1965. Upon his retirement, North suggested that the income from a tribute fund established in his name be used to publish educational materials for children. Mrs. Harriet Stryker-Rodda served as the Series Editor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 15.3: Long Island in History series contains correspondence, notes, reports, and published copies of the Long Island in History pamphlet series. There are also files related to the pamphlets' distribution to various schools on Long Island.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: From 1961 to 1969 and 1973 to 1982, the Long Island Historical Society published a periodic journal titled The Journal of Long Island History. The journals feature book reviews, president's messages, lists of library acquisitions, and essays on historical topics related to Kings, Queens, Nassau, and Suffolk counties.

processinfo.head: Processing Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 15.7: Brooklyn!: An Illustrated History contains photographs, notes, correspondence, press coverage, and promotional material related to the development and publication of Ellen Snyder-Grenier's book Brooklyn!: An Illustrated History. This book draws on themes highlighted in Brooklyn's History Museum, the Brooklyn Historical Society's first permanent exhibition, to tell the story of Brooklyn. These themes include the Brooklyn Bridge, Coney Island, the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Brooklyn Dodgers, and Brooklynites.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Brooklyn Historical Society's newsletter is a continuation of the Long Island Historical Society's newsletter, established in 1963. Following the Society's name change in 1985, the newsletter underwent a redesign and began offering more details about the society's activities. Subsequent versions of the newsletter were titled "Brooklyn History Comes to Life Magazine" and "Brooklyn History Now."

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Due to their size, the newsletters were separated and housed in oversized folders. The archivist preserved at least two copies of each newsletter. Surplus copies were discarded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series 15.9 contains correspondence, notes, photographs, mock-ups, drafts, and published copies of the Brooklyn Historical Society's newsletter. The newsletter informed BHS members and visitors about the Society's exhibitions, grant-funded projects, personnel changes, education department initiatives, public programs, acquisitions, fundraising efforts, and other important news items. The bulk of these files originated from BHS's Public Relations Office, which was responsible for compiling and distributing the newsletter, calendar of events, invitations, and press mailings.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: In the late 1990s, the education department began developing neighborhood history guides to introduce people to the history of various areas in Brooklyn. Researched and written by historians, each guide offers architectural, cultural, and historical insights into a specific Brooklyn neighborhood. Neighborhoods featured in these guides include Williamsburg, Greenpoint, Red Hook/Gowanus, Bay Ridge/Fort Hamilton, DUMBO/Vinegar Hill/Fulton Ferry, Park Slope, Flatbush, and Fort Greene/Clinton Hill.

processinfo.head: Processing Information

scopecontent.p: Contracts, settlements, claims, incident reports, license agreements, and legal agreements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports, censuses and surveys created for various state and federal entities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documentation of insurance policies held by LIHS and BHS, including for war damage, workers compensation, fine arts, and directors and officers. It also inclues correspondence, documentation of incidents that resulted in insurance claims, and an insurance appraisal by Christie's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financing proposals as well as documentation of loans from Commerce Bank, TD Bank, JP Morgan Chase, and Bank of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents relating to properties owned or occupied by BHS, including 128 Pierrepont Street, temporary offices at MetroTech, 55 Water Street and 93 Division Avenue. The sub-series also includes mortgages for a number of properties in the Society's portfolio from the 1930s-1950s, and documents relating to a 2003 Department of Design and Construction (DDC) project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various ledgers, cash books, account books and other bound financial records.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The archivist discarded documents that fell outside of BPL's record retention policy as well as any documents with employees' personal identifying information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personnel files, including offer letters, evaluations, resignation letters, separation agreements, and so forth. Additional files include staff lists, memos, policies, job descriptions, and summer intern records from the 1990s.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The archivist discarded documents that fell outside of BPL's record retention policy and/or IRS recommendations for retention schedules, as well as any documents with employees' personal identifying information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to taxes, including property and real estate taxes, tax returns (including form 990), IRS determination letters, payroll taxes, form 5500, and sales tax.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Researchers should consult CBH staff for more details.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This description will be updated with more information as processing work continues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of audiovisual material in various media documenting LIHS and BHS exhibitions, educational programs, meetings, and more. Portions of this series have been digitized.
